prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request continuum observations centred around the emission frequency of the CO 3-2 transition. The large bandwidth coverage of the continuum observations will allow us to detect CO emission from the multiple components over a wide range of velocities. Therefore if we find our targets are actually in high velocity encounters or loose groups, we should still capture their emission. Even with this consideration, the very wide bandwidth of the continuum observations should ensure a wide range of emission free channels for accurate estimatioin of the noise and background subtraction of non-galaxy sources.

We request angular resolutions of 0.5 arcseconds. At a redshift of 0.5, this corresponds to a physical scale of 3 kiloparsecs, which is on the same physical scale as the coverage of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey II's spectroscopic fibre, which will make comparisons between this intermediate redshift sample and the low redshift sample straightforward. This angular resolution also guarantees that our individual components should be detected in more than one pixel of the final image map.
The largest angular scale is indicated as 10.0 arcseconds. While the 250 micron beam is larger than 10 arcseconds, our sample selection has required that this flux be divided into smaller components than this, and we do not expect larger scale structure than 10.0 arcseconds. 10.0 arcseconds is slightly larger than 1.5 times the beam size of the 24 micron data (which has a beam of 6.0 arcseconds) and should capture all information. This largest angular scale also omits the need for additional ACA obsercations which would increase our observing time request significantly.

Our estimated fluxes are based on a conversion from the 250 mciron flux to an estimated CO 3-2 flux using a previously empirically proven correlation between the FIR and CO emission. However, since we know that our 250 micron sources are divided into at least two components, we have subsequently divided the estimated flux for the CO line into thirds. Dividing into two components would allow for shallower observations, but given that previous observations have indicated that it is possible for ALMA to resolve sources which are not traced by strong 24 micron emission, allowing for a significant detection of a third component will put much stronger upper limits on any nondetected fields. These non-detected fields will have necessarily split their flux into far more than 3 components. We therefore base our flux density estimates on the 250 micron flux being equally divided into three components. Our RMS limit is correspondingly the level required to reach a 5 sigma detection for one of the 3 components, for the weakest of the targets included in this Science Goal. However, the majority of our science targets are within 10 microJansky RMS limits of each other, so we are not over-observing any targets signficantly. To further reduce the on-sky time, we have divided the sample according to flux limit so that we do not spend time on-sky unnecessarily.
The apparent S/N across the line is poor, but as the continuum imaging still has velocity resolution of ~42 km/s, we can increase the spectral signal to noise by further binning the data in velocity spave. We do not need high spectral resolution in order to achieve our science goals, so binning the data into 300 km/s bins should be acceptable and will return us to a 5 sigma detection.

We request continuum obsercations centred around the emission frequency of the CO 3-2 transition. The large bandwidth coverage of the continuum observations will allow us to detect CO emission from multiple components over a wide range in velocity. Even if the components are found in high velocity encounters or loose groups, their emission should still be captured by the large wavelength coverage. Even with this consideration, the very wide bandwidth coverage of the continuum setup should provide a wide range of emission free channels for accurate estimation of the noise and background subtraction for non-galaxy sources.

We request angular resolutions of 0.5 arcseconds. At a redshift of 0.5, this corresponds to a physical scale of 3 kiloparsecs, which is a very good match for the average coverage of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey II's spectroscopic fibre. This will make comparisons between this intermediate sample and the low redshift data to be very straightforward. This resolutioon will also ensure that our galaxies are detected in more than one pixel in the final image.
The largest angular scale is indicated as 10 arcseconds. While the 250 micron beam is larger than this scale, our sample has already been resolved into smaller components by the 24 micron data. We therefore do not expect flux on large scales. 10.0 arcseconds is already more than 1.5 times the beam size of the 24 micron data, where the data is resolved into multiple components. 10.0 arcseconds is large enough that we do not require ACA data, which would increase our observing time significantly.

Our estimated fluxes are based on a conversion from the 250 micron flux to the CO 3-2 fluxes, using a previously empirically proven correlation between the FIR and CO emission. However, since we know that our 250 micron surces are divided into at least two components, we have subsequently divided the estimated CO flux into thirds. Dividing into two components would allow for shallower observations, but given that previous observations have indicated that it is possible for ALMA to resolve sources which are not traced by strong 24 micron emission, allowing for a significant detection of a third component will put much stronger upper limits on any non-detected fields. Any non-detected fields will necessarily have split their flux among many more than three components. Our RMS limit is therefore the level required to reach a 5 sigma detection for one of the three components, for the weakest component in this Science Goal. However, all the sources in this science goal have RMS limits of within 7 microJansky, so this does not appreciably overobserve any given source. We have divided the sample according to flux limit, so that for those galaxies which require less on-sky tiome, we do not spend telescope time unnecessarily.
The apparent S/N across the line width is currently poor, but as the continuum setup still has a velocity resolution of ~42 km/s, we can increase the spectral signal to noise by further binning the data in velocity space. We do not need high spectral resolution to achieve our science goals, so binning the data into 300 km/s bins should be acceptable and will return our flux density to a 5 sigma detection.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to obtain high resolution CO continuum data for a set of Herschel 250 micron sources at a redshift of 0.5, selected to be close pairs due to the presence of multiple resolved components observed in the 24 micron. These 250 micron sources are strong starbursts, guaranteed to be resolved into at least two components, and potentially into further components, when imaged with ALMA. The velocity resolution of the continuum data will allow us to determine relative velocities for each of the components, and allow us to map the gas content of these likely interacting systems. The CO imaging will allow us to analyze the morphology of the gas content of these galaxies; in conjunction with the 250 micron data we will be able to examine the individual star forming properties of these galaxies at an intermediate redshift and compare between both local and high redshift interacting systems.
